In August 2013, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] said that he had called for a review of U.S. surveillance activities even before Snowden had begun revealing details of the NSA's operations.{{cite news|last=Wolf|first=Z. Byron|title=Fact-checking Obama's claims about Snowden|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/08/12/politics/obama-snowden-whistleblower|publisher=CNN|date=August 13, 2013}} Obama announced that he was directing DNI Clapper "to establish a review group on intelligence and communications technologies" that would brief and later report to the president.{{cite news|last=Farivar|first=Cyrus|title=Obama's 'outside experts' surveillance review panel has deep ties to gov't|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/08/obamas-reported-outside-experts-surveillance-review-panel-has-deep-ties-to-govt/|newspaper=Ars Technica|date=August 23, 2013}} In December, the task force issued 46 recommendations that, if adopted, would subject the NSA to additional scrutiny by the courts, Congress, and the president, and would strip the NSA of the authority to infiltrate American computer systems using "[[backdoor (computing)|backdoors]]" in hardware or software. Panel member [[Geoffrey R. Stone]] said there was no evidence that the bulk collection of phone data had stopped any [[terror attacks]]. On October 31, 2013, [[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] stated that "in some cases" the NSA had "reached too far" in some of its surveillance activities, and promised that it would be stopped.[http://www.startribune.com/politics/national/230197991.html Kerry: Some NSA surveillance work reached 'too far' and will be stopped]. Star Tribune (November 1, 2013).[http://www.dw.de/us-surveillance-by-nsa-has-sometimes-reached-too-far-says-kerry/a-17198098 US surveillance by NSA has sometimes 'reached too far,' says Kerry]. DW.DE (October 31, 2013). In January 2014, James Clapper gave public testimony to a session of the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]]. He asked that "Snowden and his accomplices" return the purloined NSA documents. When Clapper was asked whether the word "accomplices" referred to journalists, Clapper's spokesperson Shawn Turner responded, "Director Clapper was referring to anyone who is assisting Edward Snowden to further threaten our national security through the unauthorized disclosure of stolen documents related to lawful foreign intelligence collection programs." {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/29/james-clapper-condemns-snowden-senate-testimony |title=James Clapper calls for Snowden and 'accomplices' to return NSA documents |last=Ackerman |first=Spencer |date=2014-01-29 |newspaper=The Guardian }} Also in January 2014, a review by the [[Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board]] (PCLOB) concluded that the NSA's collection of every U.S. phone record on a daily basis violates the legal restrictions of the statute cited to authorize it. "The Section 215 bulk telephone records program," PCLOB reported, "lacks a viable legal foundation under Section 215 [of the [[Patriot Act]]], implicates constitutional concerns under the First and Fourth Amendments, raises serious threats to privacy and civil liberties as a policy matter, and has shown only limited value. As a result, the Board recommends that the government end the program."{{cite web|title=Report on the Telephone Records Program Conducted under Section 215 |url=http://www.pclob.gov/All%20Documents/Report%20on%20the%20Telephone%20Records%20Program/PCLOB-Report-on-the-Telephone-Records-Program.pdf |agency=Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board|date=January 23, 2014}} The White House rejected the findings, saying "We simply disagree with the board's analysis on the legality of the program."{{cite news|title=White House rejects review board finding that NSA data sweep is illegal|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/01/23/independent-federal-review-board-says-nsa-phone-data-collection-program-should/|work=Fox/AP|accessdate=January 29, 2014|date=January 23, 2014}} A second PCLOB review, in July 2014, concluded that the NSA's surveillance program targeting foreigners overseas is lawful, under Section 702 of the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 Amendments Act of 2008|FISA Amendments Act of 2008]], and effective but that certain elements push "close to the line" of being unconstitutional.{{cite news|last=Nakashima|first=Ellen|title=Independent panel: NSA surveillance program targeting foreigners is lawful|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/independent-panel-nsa-surveillance-program-targeting-foreigners-is-lawful/2014/07/01/2b749fa2-018c-11e4-b8ff-89afd3fad6bd_story.html|work=The Washington Post| date=July 1, 2014}} The July report said that the Board was "impressed with the rigor of the government’s efforts to ensure that it acquires only those communications it is authorized to collect, and that it targets only those persons it is authorized to target. Moreover, the government has taken seriously its obligations to establish and adhere to a detailed set of rules regarding how it handles U.S. person communications that it acquires under the program."[http://www.pclob.gov/All%20Documents/Report%20on%20the%20Section%20702%20Program/PCLOB-Section-702-Report.pdf Report on the Surveillance Program Operated Pursuant to Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act] [[Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board]] p. 103, 2 July 2014 === Congress === Reactions to the global surveillance disclosures among members of the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] initially were largely negative.{{cite news|last=Reeve|first=Elspeth|title=Washington turns on the NSA blinders to target weird 'IT guy' leaker instead|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2013/06/edward-snowden-washington-response/66063/|newspaper=The Atlantic Wire|date=June 10, 2013}} [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] [[John Boehner]]{{cite news |title=John Boehner: Edward Snowden Is A 'Traitor' |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=June 11, 2013 |last= LoGiurato |first= Brett |url= http://www.sfgate.com/technology/businessinsider/article/JOHN-BOEHNER-Edward-Snowden-Is-A-Traitor-4593261.php |accessdate=June 11, 2013}} and senators [[Dianne Feinstein]]{{cite news |last1=Herb |first1=Jeremy |last2=Sink |first2=Justin |title=Sen. Feinstein calls Snowden's NSA leaks an 'act of treason' |publisher=thehill.com |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/defcon-hill/policy-and-strategy/304573-sen-feinstein-snowdens-leaks-are-treason |date=June 10, 2013}} and [[Bill Nelson (politician)|Bill Nelson]]{{cite news|last=Nelson|first=Bill|title=This man is a traitor|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/man-traitor-article-1.1369682|newspaper=Daily News|location=New York|date=June 11, 2013}} called Snowden a traitor, and several senators and representatives joined them in calling for Snowden's arrest and prosecution.{{cite news |title=Edward Snowden: Ex-CIA leaker drops out of sight, faces legal battle |agency=Reuters |work=The Chicago Tribune |date=June 10, 2013 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-06-10/news/chi-edward-snowden-nsa-leaks-20130610_1_u-s-justice-department-regina-ip-hong-kong |accessdate=June 12, 2013}}{{cite news |title=DNC chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz: Snowden is a coward |first=Aaron|last=Blake|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 11, 2013 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/06/11/dnc-chair-debbie-wasserman-schultz-snowden-is-a-coward/ |accessdate=June 13, 2013}} Arizona Senator [[John McCain]] criticized politicians who voted in favor of the PATRIOT Act but were outraged by the NSA spying on phone calls by saying, "We passed the Patriot Act. We passed specific provisions of the act that allowed for this program to take place, to be enacted in operation. Now, if members of Congress did not know what they were voting on, then I think that that's their responsibility a lot more than it is the government's."{{cite news| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/06/09/senators-should-have-known-about-snooping-says-mccain/ | work=CNN | title=Senators should have known about snooping, says McCain | date=June 9, 2013}} In July 2013, the [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|U.S. Senate Committee on Appropriations]] unanimously adopted an amendment by Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] to the "Fiscal Year 2014 Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Appropriations Bill"{{USBill|113|s|1372|site=yes}}. [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/113/s1372 S. 1372] at [[GovTrack]]. [http://www.opencongress.org/bill/113-s1372/ S. 1372] at [[OpenCongress]]. that would have sought sanctions against any country offering asylum to Snowden.{{cite news|title=U.S. lawmakers want sanctions on any country taking in Snowden|first=Patricia|last=Zengerle|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=July 25, 2013|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/25/us-usa-security-congress-idUSBRE96O18220130725}}{{cite news|title=U.S. Senate advances law pressuring Russia not to give Snowden asylum|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency|Xinhua]]|date=July 26, 2013|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2013-07/26/c_132574418.htm}}{{cite podcast|title=FY14 Full Committee Markup of State-Foreign Operations, and Financial Services General Government Bills|date=July 25, 2013|publisher=[[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations]]|time=1:10:08|url=http://www.appropriations.senate.gov/webcasts.cfm?method=webcasts.view&id=591353fa-8fd0-41e9-9d7e-6adf0ab76537}} Also in July 2013, Rep. [[Justin Amash]] (R-Mich.) and Rep. [[John Conyers]] (D-Mich.) proposed the "[[Amash–Conyers Amendment]]" to the National Defense Authorization Act.{{cite news|last=Ehrenfreund|first=Max|title=House proposal to curtail NSA in response to Edward Snowden's leaks fails narrowly|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/house-proposal-to-curtail-nsa-in-response-to-edward-snowdens-leaks-fails-narrowly/2013/07/25/b7117338-f54d-11e2-9434-60440856fadf_story.html|accessdate=July 29, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=July 25, 2013}} If passed, the amendment would have curtailed "the ongoing dragnet collection and storage of the personal records of innocent Americans." The House rejected the amendment by a vote of 205–217.{{cite news|title=The Amash Amendment Fails, Barely|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2013/07/amash-amendment-fails-despite-democratic-support/67584/|accessdate=July 29, 2013|newspaper=The Atlantic Wire|date=July 24, 2013|author1=Abby Ohlheiser |author2=Philip Bump |lastauthoramp=yes }} An analysis indicated that those who voted against the amendment received 122% more in campaign contributions from defense contractors than those who voted in favor.{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2013/07/money-nsa-vote/|title =Lawmakers Who Upheld NSA Phone Spying Received Double the Defense Industry Cash|last=Kravets |first=David|date =July 26, 2013 |accessdate=August 3, 2013|work=Wired}} In September 2013, Senators [[Mark Udall]], [[Richard Blumenthal]], [[Rand Paul]] and [[Ron Wyden]] introduced a "sweeping surveillance reform" proposal.{{cite web|last=Serwer|first=Adam|title=New calls for surveillance reform after Snowden|url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/new-calls-surveillance-reform-after|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=October 18, 2013|date=September 25, 2013}} Called the most comprehensive proposal to date, the "Intelligence Oversight and Surveillance Reform Act" seeks to end the bulk collection of communication records made legal in section 215 of the [[Patriot Act]] and to reign in other "electronic eavesdropping programs".{{cite news|last=Zengerle|first=Patricia|title=U.S. lawmakers seek to end bulk NSA telephone records collection|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/25/us-cybersecurity-law-congress-idUSBRE98O1BU20130925|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 18, 2013|date=September 25, 2013}} Wyden told ''The Guardian'' the Snowden disclosures have "caused a sea change in the way the public views the surveillance system". The draft bill is a blend of 12 similar proposals as well as other legislative proposals.{{cite news|title=NSA reform bill to trim back US surveillance unveiled in Congress|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/25/nsa-reform-bill-surveillance-congress|accessdate=October 18, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 25, 2013|author1=Paul Lewis |author2=Dan Roberts |lastauthoramp=yes |location=Washington}} In October 2013, Congressman [[Jim Sensenbrenner]], author of the [[Patriot Act]], introduced a proposal to the House of Representatives called the [[USA Freedom Act]] to end the bulk collection of Americans' metadata and reform the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]] (FISA) court.[https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2013/10/10/patriot-act-author-seeks-usa-freedom-act-to-rein-in-nsa 'Patriot Act' Author Seeks 'USA Freedom Act' to Rein In NSA – US News and World Report]. Usnews.com (October 10, 2013). Senators introduced two different reform proposals. One, the [[USA Freedom Act]] (H.R. 3361/ S. 1599),{{cite news|last=Roberts|first=Dan|title=The USA Freedom Act: a look at the key points of the draft bill|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/10/the-usa-freedom-act-a-look-at-the-key-points-of-the-draft-bill|accessdate=November 1, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=October 10, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Risen|first=Tom|title=Freedom Act to End NSA Data Collection Introduced|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2013/10/29/freedom-act-to-end-nsa-data-collection-introduced|accessdate=November 1, 2013|newspaper=US News|date=October 29, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Sensenbrenner|first=Congressman Jim|title=The USA FREEDOM Act|url=http://sensenbrenner.house.gov/legislation/theusafreedomact.htm|accessdate=November 1, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Bill Summary & Status - 113th Congress (2013 - 2014) - H.R.3361 - CRS Summary|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d113:HR03361:@@@D&summ2=m&|work=Congressional Research Service|publisher=THOMAS (Library of Congress)|accessdate=18 December 2013|date=29 October 2013}} would effectively halt “bulk” records collection under the USA Patriot Act, while it also would require a warrant to deliberately search for the e-mail and phone call content of Americans that is collected as part of a surveillance program targeting foreigners located overseas. Another proposal is the [[FISA Improvements Act]] that would preserve the program while strengthening privacy protections. It would also codifying the requirement that analysts have a “reasonable articulable suspicion” that a phone number is associated with terrorism to query the NSA phone records database; requiring that the FISA court promptly review each such determination; and limiting the retention period for phone records. Both proposals share the introduction of a special advocate to promote privacy interests before the FISA court.{{cite news|last=Nakashima|first=Ellen|title=NSA bills set up a choice in Congress: End bulk collection of phone records or endorse it|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-bills-set-up-a-choice-in-congress-end-bulk-collection-of-phone-records-or-endorse-it/2013/10/28/99007880-3fd5-11e3-a751-f032898f2dbc_story.html|accessdate=November 1, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 29, 2013}} === Judiciary === In April 2014, ''The Washington Post'' reported that some federal judges holding low-level positions had been balking at sweeping requests by law enforcement for cellphone and other sensitive personal data. The ''Post'' called it "a small but growing faction, including judges in Texas, Kansas, New York and Pennsylvania," and said the judges deemed the requests overly broad and at odds with basic constitutional rights. Although some rulings were overturned, said the ''Post,'' their decisions have shaped when and how investigators can seize information detailing the locations, communications and online histories of Americans. Albert Gidari Jr., a partner at [[Perkins Coie]] who represents technology and telecommunications companies, told the ''Post'' that these judges "don't want to be the ones who approve an order that later becomes public and embarrassing…. Nobody likes to be characterized as a rubber stamp." According to the ''Post,'' some legal observers have called this "the Magistrates' Revolt," which began several years ago; however, it gained power amid mounting public anger about government surveillance capabilities after the NSA disclosures.{{cite news|title=Low-level federal judges balking at law enforcement requests for electronic evidence|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/low-level-federal-judges-balking-at-law-enforcement-requests-for-electronic-evidence/2014/04/24/eec81748-c01b-11e3-b195-dd0c1174052c_story.html|work=WashingtonPost|accessdate=25 April 2014|first1=Ann E.|last1=Marimow|first2=Craig|last2=Timberg|date=April 25, 2014}} ====Lawsuits==== In the wake of the NSA leaks, conservative public interest lawyer and [[Judicial Watch]] founder [[Larry Klayman]] filed a lawsuit claiming that the federal government had unlawfully collected metadata for his telephone calls and was harassing him (see ''[[Klayman v. Obama]]''), and the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) filed a lawsuit against Director of National Intelligence James Clapper alleging that the NSA's phone records program was unconstitutional (see ''[[ACLU v. Clapper]]''). Once the judge in each case had issued rulings seemingly at odds with one another, Gary Schmitt (former staff director of the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]]) wrote in ''[[The Weekly Standard]]'', "The two decisions have generated public confusion over the constitutionality of the NSA's data collection program—a kind of judicial 'he-said, she-said' standoff." {{citation |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/tale-two-judges_773264.html |title=A Tale of Two Judges |last=Schmitt |first=Gary |date=2014-01-13 |publisher=''The Weekly Standard'' |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote=The NSA on trial. |accessdate=March 9, 2014 }} ===State governments=== {{Main|Fourth Amendment Protection Act}} Legislators in several states introduced bills based upon a [[model act]], written by anti-surveillance activists, called the "Fourth Amendment Protection Act". {{citation |url=http://rt.com/usa/nsa-water-supply-bill-265/ |title=US senators propose bill to shut off NSA's water supply in California |date=2014-01-07 |publisher=TV-Novosti |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= Based on the model legislation—the Fourth Amendment Protection Act—first drafted by the Tenth Amendment Center and activists at the Offnow coalition [...] }} The bills seek to prohibit state governments from co-operating with the NSA in various ways: the Utah bill would prohibit provision of water to NSA facilities; {{citation |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9245232/California_lawmakers_move_to_bar_state_help_to_NSA |title=California lawmakers move to bar state help to NSA |last=Vijayan |first=Jaikumar |date=2014-01-07 |publisher=Computer World |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote=The Utah bill aims to prohibit state and local agencies from providing water to a giant new NSA data center near Salt Lake City. }} the California bill would prohibit state universities from conducting research for the NSA; {{cite press release |url=http://offnow.org/2014/01/06/california-lawmakers-introduce-fourth-amendment-protection-act/ |title=California Lawmakers Introduce Fourth Amendment Protection Act, push back against NSA spying |date=2014-01-06 |publisher= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= Blocks public universities from serving as NSA research facilities or recruiting grounds. }} and the Kansas bill would require a search warrant for data collection. {{citation |url=http://www.shawneedispatch.com/news/2014/jan/06/shawnee-legislator-files-fourth-amendment-protecti/ |title=Shawnee legislator files Fourth Amendment Protection Act |last=Rothschild |first=Scott |date=2014-01-06 |publisher=Shawnee Dispatch |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote=[...] would prevent state/local agencies in Kansas from searching or obtaining personal electronic data [...] without a warrant [...] }} ===Public protests=== [[File:-FsA14 - Freiheit statt Angst 060 (15062050686) (2).jpg|thumb|Demonstration in Berlin, Germany, August 30, 2014]] The disclosures have inspired public protests. ==== "Restore the Fourth"==== {{main|Restore the Fourth}} After the June 2013 release, a [[political movement]] known as "''[[Restore the Fourth]]''" was formed in the United States and rapidly gained momentum. In early July, ''Restore the Fourth'' was responsible for protests in more than 80 cities including Seattle, San Francisco, Denver, Chicago, Los Angeles and New York City. These protests were loosely coordinated via online messaging services and involved protestors from all over the United States.{{cite news|last=Heather|first=Kelly|title=Protests against the NSA spring up across U.S.|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/04/tech/web/restore-nsa-protests|publisher=CNN|accessdate=August 13, 2013|date=July 5, 2013}} ==== "Stop Watching Us"==== [[File:Stop watching us 0503.JPG|thumb|"Stop Watching US" rally in Washington DC, October 26, 2013]] On October 26, 2013, an anti-NSA rally called "[[Stop Watching Us]]" was held in Washington, D.C., billed by organizers as the "largest rally yet to protest mass surveillance". A diverse coalition of over 100 advocacy groups organized the event and attracted thousands of protesters calling for an end to mass surveillance.{{cite news|author1=Bart Jansen |author2=Carolyn Pesce |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Anti-NSA rally attracts thousands to march in Washington|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/10/26/nsa-dc-rally/3241417/|publisher=''[[USA Today]]''|accessdate=October 27, 2013|date=October 26, 2013}} Speakers included former governor [[Gary Johnson]] and NSA whistleblower [[Thomas Andrews Drake|Thomas Drake]].{{cite news|author=Bart Jansen and Carolyn Pesce, USA TODAY |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/10/26/nsa-dc-rally/3241417/ |title=Anti-NSA rally attracts thousands to march in Washington |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=October 26, 2013 |accessdate=November 1, 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/26/nsa-rally-stop-watching-washington-snowden|title=Thousands gather in Washington for anti-NSA 'Stop Watching Us' rally|first=Jim|last=Newell|date=26 October 2013|publisher=|via=The Guardian}} ===="The Day We Fight Back"==== {{Main|The Day We Fight Back}} "The Day We Fight Back" is an ongoing protest against [[mass surveillance]] by the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA){{cite news |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2086880/advocacy-groups-plan-day-of-protest-against-nsa-surveillance.html |title=Advocacy groups plan day of protest against NSA surveillance |work=[[PC World]] |first=Grant |last=Gross |date=January 10, 2014 |accessdate=January 14, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mintpressnews.com/activists-announce-day-to-fight-back-against-nsa/176890/ |title=Activists Announce Day To ‘Fight Back’ Against NSA |publisher=MintPress News |first=Katie |last=Rucke |date=January 14, 2014 |accessdate=January 14, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/reddit-mozilla-others-protest-nsa-spying-honor-aaron-swartz-day-we-fight-back-1538148 |title=Reddit, Mozilla And Others To Protest NSA Spying, Honor Aaron Swartz On 'The Day We Fight Back' |work=[[International Business Times]] |first=Eric |last=Brown |date=January 14, 2014 |accessdate=January 14, 2014}} scheduled for February 11, 2014. The 'day of action' primarily took the form of webpage banner-advertisements urging viewers to contact their lawmakers over issues surrounding cyber surveillance and a free Internet. By February 10, more than 5,700 websites and organizations had signed up to show support by featuring ''The Day We a Fight Back'' banner for 24 hours.{{cite news| url=http://swampland.time.com/2014/02/10/the-day-we-fight-back-protests-nsa-surveillance/ |title='The Day We Fight Back' Protests NSA Surveillance |work=Time}} [[File:The Day We Fight Back - banner.jpg|thumb|left|The banner of The Day We Fight Back, February 11, 2014]] As February 11 drew to a close, ''[[The New York Times]]'' posted a blog titled "The Day the Internet Didn't Fight Back," reporting that "the protest on Tuesday barely registered. [[Wikipedia]] did not participate. [[Reddit]] … added an inconspicuous banner to its homepage. Sites like [[Tumblr]], [[Mozilla]] and [[DuckDuckGo]], which were listed as organizers, did not include the banner on their homepages. The eight major technology companies—[[Google]], [[Microsoft]], [[Facebook]], [[AOL]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Twitter]], [[Yahoo]] and [[LinkedIn]] … only participated Tuesday insofar as having a joint website flash the protest banner."{{cite news |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/02/11/the-day-the-internet-didnt-fight-back/ |title=The Day the Internet Didn't Fight Back |work=[[The New York Times]] |series=Bits |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth |date=February 11, 2014 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}} {{clear}} === Non-government organization === An analysis released by the [[New America Foundation]] in January 2014 reviewed 225 terrorism cases since the [[September 11 attacks]] found that the NSA's bulk collection of phone records "has had no discernible impact on preventing acts of terrorism," and that U.S. government claims of the program's usefulness were "overblown."{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-phone-record-collection-does-little-to-prevent-terrorist-attacks-group-says/2014/01/12/8aa860aa-77dd-11e3-8963-b4b654bcc9b2_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Ellen | last=Nakashima | title=National Security | date=January 12, 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/01/13/262098004/review-of-terrorism-cases-finds-nsa-spying-helped-very-little|title=Review Of Terrorism Cases Finds NSA Spying Helped Very Little|publisher=}} ==International response== ===Asia=== ==== China ==== On June 17, 2013, nearly two weeks after the first disclosure was published, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Foreign Ministry]] spokeswoman [[Hua Chunying]] said at a daily briefing, "We believe the United States should pay attention to the international community's concerns and demands and give the international community the necessary explanation."{{cite news|title=China asks U.S. to explain Internet surveillance|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/17/us-usa-security-china-idUSBRE95G06R20130617|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 24, 2013|date=June 17, 2013}} ===== Hong Kong===== The ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' published a poll of Hong Kong residents conducted while Snowden was still in Hong Kong that showed that half of the 509 respondents believed the Chinese government should not surrender Snowden to the United States if Washington raises such a request; 33 percent of those polled think of Snowden as a hero, 12.8 percent described him as a traitor, 36 percent said he was neither.{{cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1261483/one-2-hongkongers-say-snowden-should-not-be-surrendered-us |title=Hongkongers don't want Snowden handed over to the US, according to poll |newspaper=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong |first=Joshua |last=But |date=June 16, 2013 |accessdate=June 17, 2013}} {{multiple image | align = right | footer = Hong Kong demonstration at US Consulate on June 15 in support of Snowden | width = 150 | image1 = Protesters rally in Hong Kong to support Edward Snowden 01.jpg | alt1 = | image2 = Protesters rally in Hong Kong to support Edward Snowden 02.jpg | alt2 = | image3 = Protesters rally in Hong Kong to support Edward Snowden 10.jpg | alt3 = }} Referring to Snowden's presence in the territory, Hong Kong chief executive [[Leung Chun Ying|Leung Chun-Ying]] assured that the government would "handle the case of Mr Snowden in accordance with the laws and established procedures of Hong Kong [and] follow up on any incidents related to the privacy or other rights of the institutions or people in Hong Kong being violated."{{cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1261593/cy-leung-breaks-silence-snowden-case-we-will-follow-privacy-claims |title=HK, US govt lawyers 'not working together' on Snowden, say sources as CY breaks silence |newspaper=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong |date=June 16, 2013}} [[Pro-democracy camp in Hong Kong|Pan-democrat]] legislators [[Gary Fan]] and [[Claudia Mo]] said that the perceived U.S. prosecution against Snowden will set "a dangerous precedent and will likely be used to justify similar actions" by authoritarian governments.{{cite news |url= http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/kyodo-news-international/130615/hk-lawmakers-petition-obama-leniency-against-whistlebl |title=H.K. lawmakers petition Obama for leniency against whistleblower |work=Kyodo News International |date=June 13, 2013 |last=Fraser |first=Niall |accessdate=June 15, 2013}} During Snowden's stay, the two main political groups, the pan-democrats and [[Pro-Beijing camp]], found rare agreement to support Snowden.{{cite news|last=Ma|first=Mary|date=June 20, 2013|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=49&art_id=134784&sid=39840738&con_type=1&d_str=20130620&isSearch=1&sear_year=2013|title=Ip in security minister's shoes|work=The Standard|location=Hong Kong|quote=However, surrounding the Snowden case is something never before seen in local politics. Not only are the pan-democrat and pro-establishment camps singing off the same song sheet, the pan-democrats and mainland propagandists are humming a similar tune.}}{{cite news|last=Lau|first=Stuart|date=June 24, 2013|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1267574/edward-snowden-passing-snowstorm-made-allies-hong-kong-foes|title=Hong Kong's political foes made allies amid Edward Snowden storm|postscript=. Print title: "Passing snowstorm made allies of foes".|work=South China Morning Post|location=Hong Kong|accessdate=June 24, 2013|quote=Snowden's arrival in the city gave Hong Kong a rare place in the global geopolitical spotlight and ushered in near-unprecedented political solidarity as pan-democrats and Beijing loyalists lined up to take a shot at an unlikely target: the United States.}} The pro-Beijing [[Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong|DAB party]] even organised a separate march to Government headquarters for Snowden. [[People's Daily|The ''People's Daily'']] and the ''[[Global Times]]'' editorials of June 19 stated respectively that the central Chinese government was unwilling to be involved in a "mess" caused by others, and that the Hong Kong government should follow the public opinion and not concern itself with Sino-US relations.{{cite news|last=Zuo|first=Mandy|date=June 20, 2013|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1264604/newspaper-commentaries-suggest-beijing-wants-hong-kong-handle-snowden-its|title=Beijing wants Hong Kong to handle Snowden on its own, party newspapers suggest|postscript=. In print as "Articles highlight possible Beijing role".|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|location=Hong Kong|accessdate=June 20, 2013}} A [[Tsinghua University]] communications studies specialist, Liu Jianming, interpreted that the two articles as suggesting that the mainland government did not want further involvement in the case and that the Hong Kong government should handle it independently. After Snowden left Hong Kong, Chinese-language newspapers such as the ''[[Ming Pao]]'' and the ''[[Oriental Daily]]'' expressed relief that Hong Kong no longer had to shoulder the burden of the Snowden situation.{{cite news |author= Lai Ying-kit |url= http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1268012/edward-snowdens-depature-seen-relief-chinese-language-newspapers |title=Edward Snowden's depature [sic] seen as a relief: Chinese-language newspapers |work=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong |date=June 24, 2013 |accessdate=June 24, 2013}} Mainland experts said that, although the Central Government did not want to appear to be intervening in the matter, it was inconceivable that the Hong Kong government acted independently in a matter that could have far-reaching consequences for Sino-US relations. One expert suggested that, by doing so, China had "returned the favor" for their not having accepted the [[Wang Lijun incident|asylum plea from Wang Lijun]] in February 2012.{{cite news |title= Beijing made final decision, say analysts |page=2 |work=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong |date=June 25, 2013}} The official Chinese Communist Party mouthpiece, the ''[[People's Daily]]'' denied the US government accusation that the PRC central government had allowed Snowden to escape, and said that Snowden helped in "tearing off Washington's sanctimonious mask."{{cite news |last=Kaiman |first=Jonathan |date=June 25, 2013 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/25/peoples-daily-savages-us-over-snowden |title=China's state newspaper praises Edward Snowden for 'tearing off Washington's sanctimonious mask' |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=June 25, 2013}} ====Malaysia==== On November 2, 2013, the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Malaysia)|Malaysian Foreign Minister]] [[Anifah Aman]] summoned the ambassadors of Australia and the United States to protest an alleged American-led spying network in Asia.{{cite web|title=Malaysia protests at 'US and Australia spying' in Asia|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-24784895|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=November 2, 2013}} === Europe === ==== European Union ==== Early in July 2013, the European Commissioner for Home Affairs, [[Cecilia Malmström]], wrote to two U.S. officials that "mutual trust and confidence have been seriously eroded and I expect the U.S. to do all that it can to restore them".{{cite news|title=European Union threatens to stop sharing data with United States over spying reports |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/eu-threatens-stop-sharing-data-u-s-spying-reports-article-1.1391702|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|accessdate=July 8, 2013}} On October 20, 2013, a committee at the [[European Parliament]] backed a measure that, if enacted, would require American companies to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking private data. The legislation has been under consideration for two years. The vote is part of efforts in Europe to shield citizens from online surveillance in the wake of revelations about a far-reaching spying program by NSA.[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/22/business/international/eu-panel-backs-plan-to-shield-online-data.html "Rules Shielding Online Data From N.S.A. and Other Prying Eyes Advance in Europe"], James Kanter and Mike Scott, ''New York Times'', October 21, 2013. Retrieved October 22, 2013. The [[European Council]] meeting at the end of October 2013 in its statement signed by all 28 EU leaders while stressing that "intelligence gathering is a vital element in the fight against terrorism" and noting "the close relationship between Europe and the USA and the value of that partnership", said that this must "be based on respect and trust," a lack of which "could prejudice the necessary cooperation in the field of intelligence gathering".{{cite web|title=EU-US spying row stokes concern over anti-terror campaign |url=http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/us-intelligence.r38|work=EU Business|date=October 26, 2013|accessdate=October 26, 2013}}{{cite news|title=EU says distrust of US on spying may harm terror fight |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24668286|work=BBC|date=October 25, 2013|accessdate=October 26, 2013}} On December 23, 2013, the European Parliament released the results{{cite web|last=Moreas|first=Claude|title=DRAFT REPORT on the US NSA surveillance programme, surveillance bodies in various Member States and their impact on EU citizens’ fundamental rights and on transatlantic cooperation in Justice and Home Affairs. (2013/2188(INI))|url=http://www.statewatch.org/news/2014/jan/ep-draft-nsa-surveillance-report.pdf|publisher=European Parliament Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs|accessdate=13 January 2014|date=23 December 2013}} of its inquiry into the NSA activities.{{cite news|title=NSA and GCHQ activities appear illegal, says EU parliamentary inquiry|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/09/nsa-gchq-illegal-european-parliamentary-inquiry|accessdate=14 January 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=9 January 2014|author1=Nick Hopkins |author2=Ian Traynor |lastauthoramp=yes }} "The European Parliament's committee inquiry into the spying scandal," [[Deutsche Welle]] reported, "was the first of this scale. No individual EU country has looked into the scandal this thoroughly and no EU government has been as explicit in its criticism of the US government." The draft report covered the preceding six months and was, said Deutsche Welle, "hard on all sides—including governments and companies in the EU." Presented by [[Claude Moraes]], British [[Member of the European Parliament]] from the [[Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats]], the report found what it called "compelling evidence of the existence of far-reaching, complex and highly technologically advanced systems designed by US and some Member States' intelligence services to collect, store and analyze communication and location data and metadata of all citizens around the world on an unprecedented scale and in an indiscriminate and non-suspicion-based manner." The fight against terrorism, said the report, can "never in itself be a justification for untargeted, secret and sometimes even illegal mass surveillance programs."{{cite web|last=Haase|first=Nina|title=EU report reveals massive scope of secret NSA surveillance|url=http://www.dw.de/eu-report-reveals-massive-scope-of-secret-nsa-surveillance/a-17352243|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=13 January 2014}} However, Moreas and his fellow rapporteurs considered it "very doubtful that data collection of such magnitude is only guided by the fight against terrorism, as it involves the collection of all possible data of all citizens; points therefore to the possible existence of other power motives such as political and [[economic espionage]]." ====France==== On October 21, 2013, France summoned [[Charles Rivkin]], the U.S. Ambassador to France, to clarify and explain the NSA's surveillance of French citizens.{{cite news|title=France summons U.S. ambassador over spying report|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/21/us-france-nsa-idUSBRE99K04920131021|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 24, 2013|date=October 21, 2013}} Speaking to journalists, President [[François Hollande]] said, "We cannot accept this kind of behaviour between partners and allies. We ask that this immediately stop."{{cite web|last=Michael Mainville|title=France warns US spying claims threaten trade talks|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/frances-hollande-tells-us-immediately-stop-spying-005339477.html|publisher=AFP|date=July 2, 2013}} According to ''The Wall Street Journal'', data allegedly collected by the NSA in France was actually collected by French intelligence agencies outside France and then shared with the United States. ====Germany==== [[File:View from Reichstag to Brandenburg Gate and US Embassy.JPG|thumb|right|A view from the rooftop terrace of the [[Reichstag building]] in [[Berlin]], the seat of the German parliament. In the background, behind the [[Brandenburg Gate]], the [[Embassy of the United States, Berlin|United States Embassy]] can be seen. The grey structure on the embassy's roof (top right corner of the photograph) is thought to contain surveillance equipment, possibly used to tap into mobile phones.{{cite journal|title=NSA-Spähskandal: So funktionieren die Abhöranlagen in US-Botschaften|journal=[[Spiegel Online]]|date=October 28, 2013|url=http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/netzpolitik/nsa-spaehskandal-so-funktionieren-die-abhoeranlagen-in-us-botschaften-a-930392.html|accessdate=October 30, 2013}} ]] [[File:Berlin 2013 PRISM Demo.jpg|thumb|Demonstration of the [[Pirate Party Germany|Pirate Party of Germany]] against PRISM in Berlin, Germany, 2013.]] According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', "The outcry over NSA eavesdropping has been most pronounced in Germany, a country whose history of dictatorship has left the population particularly sensitive to violations of personal privacy."{{cite news| url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303874504579372832399168684?mg=reno64-wsj |title=NSA Flap Strains Ties With Europe |work=The Wall Street Journal}} It was revealed that, beginning in 2002, German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s phone has been "on an NSA target list".{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/nsa-spied-schroeder-iraq-648/|title=NSA spied on Germany’s Schroeder over Iraq War opposition - report|publisher=}} It was reported that the NSA also spied on then-Chancellor [[Gerhard Schroeder]] starting in 2002 after the Schroeder criticized plans for the invasion of Iraq. On July 1, 2013, the [[Foreign Office (Germany)|German Foreign Ministry]] summoned [[Philip D. Murphy]], the U.S. Ambassador to Germany, over allegations that the NSA had spied on institutions of the European Union.{{cite news|title=German Foreign Ministry Summons US Ambassador Over NSA Spying Claims|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20130701-702136.html|publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'|date=July 1, 2013|quote=Seeking clarification on the matter, the foreign ministry has called the U.S. ambassador to Germany, Philip Murphy, for a meeting later Monday, a spokesman for the ministry said.}} Towards the end of July, the media reported that Germany's foreign intelligence agency, the [[Bundesnachrichtendienst]] (BND), had been actively cooperating with the NSA, which sparked demonstrations in 40 German cities involving thousands of protesters all over the country.{{cite web|title=Thousands fill German streets to protest Berlin's NSA spying involvement|url=http://rt.com/news/germany-nsa-merkel-writers-669/|publisher=RT|location=Russia|accessdate=August 13, 2013}} In early August 2013, Germany canceled largely symbolic [[Cold War]]-era administrative agreements with Britain, the United States and France, which had granted the Western countries which had troops stationed in West Germany the right to request surveillance operations to protect those forces.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-23553837|title=Germany ends spy pact with US and UK after Snowden|publisher=BBC |date=August 2, 2013}} At the end of August, under the orders of the [[Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution|German domestic intelligence agency]], a federal police helicopter conducted a low-altitude flyover of the [[Consulate General of the United States, Frankfurt|United States Consulate]] in [[Frankfurt]], apparently in search of suspected clandestine eavesdropping facilities. A German official called it a symbolic "shot across the bow."[http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/german-helicopter-searched-for-nsa-listening-post-in-frankfurt-a-921257.html German Helicopter Searched For NSA Listening Post In Frankfurt] SPIEGEL ONLINE. On October 24, 2013, EU heads of state met to discuss a proposed data protection law. The representatives of Italy, Poland and France wanted the law to be passed before the May 2014 European Parliament elections. Germany, represented by [[Angela Merkel]], and the UK, represented by [[David Cameron]], favored a slower implementation; their wishes prevailed. About the "[[Five Eyes]]" espionage alliance, Merkel remarked, "Unlike David, we are unfortunately not part of this group." {{citation |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/germany-impedes-eu-privacy-efforts-despite-outrage-at-nsa-spying-a-930488.html |title=Appearances and Reality: Merkel Balks at EU Privacy Push |last=Schmitz |first=Gregor Peter |date=2013-10-28 |publisher=Der Spiegel |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101013642/http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/germany-impedes-eu-privacy-efforts-despite-outrage-at-nsa-spying-a-930488.html |archivedate=2013-11-01 |quote= |deadurl=no }} Also on October 24, the Foreign Ministry summoned [[John B. Emerson]], the U.S. Ambassador to Germany, to clarify allegations that the NSA had tapped into Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]]’s mobile phone.{{cite web|title=German foreign minister summons US ambassador over Merkel spying allegations|url=http://www.dw.de/german-foreign-minister-summons-us-ambassador-over-merkel-spying-allegations/a-17180294|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]|accessdate=October 24, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA spying allegations: Are US allies really shocked?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24676392|publisher=BBC|date=October 26, 2013|accessdate=October 26, 2013}} While the German government had hoped for a "no spy" agreement with the U.S., by January 2014 it was reported that Germany had "given up hope" of securing such a treaty.{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.de/20140114/germany-gives-up-hope-of-no-spy-deal-with-nsa-usa|title=Germans abandon hope of US 'no-spy' treaty|date=14 January 2014|publisher=}} The Foreign Office's [[Philipp Mißfelder]] declared that "the current situation in transatlantic relations is worse than it was at the low-point in 2003 during the Iraq War".http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2014/01/17/22338261-us-germany-relations-hit-new-low-amid-nsa-spying-scandal-official-says?lite The [[German Parliamentary Committee investigating the NSA spying scandal]] was started on March 20, 2014, by the [[German Parliament]] in order to investigate the extent and background of foreign secret services spying in Germany and to search for strategies on how to protect German telecommunication with technical means.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} It was revealed that Germany's [[Federal Intelligence Service (Germany)|BND]] intelligence service has covertly monitored European defence interests and politicians inside Germany at the request of the NSA."[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11562072/German-spies-monitored-European-targets-for-the-US-against-German-interests.html German spies 'monitored European targets for the US against German interests']". ''The Daily Telegraph.'' 24 April 2015. ====Italy==== Italy's Prime Minister [[Enrico Letta]] asked [[John Kerry]], the U.S. Secretary of State, to clarify if the NSA had illegally intercepted telecommunications in Italy.{{cite web|title=Italy Presses Kerry Over US Surveillance|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/reu-italy-presses-kerry-over-us-surveillance/1775519.html|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|accessdate=October 24, 2013}} On October 23, 2013, the [[Italian Minister of the Interior|Italian Interior Minister]] [[Angelino Alfano]] told reporters, "We have a duty to [provide] clarity to Italian citizens—we must obtain the whole truth and tell the whole truth, without regard for anyone."{{cite web|title=Letta quizzes Kerry on US spy claims|url=http://www.gazzettadelsud.it/news/english/66340/Letta-quizzes-Kerry-on-US-spy-claims.html|publisher=''[[Gazzetta del Sud]]''|accessdate=October 24, 2013}} ====Spain==== On October 25, 2013, the Spanish Prime Minister [[Mariano Rajoy]] summoned [[James Costos]], the U.S. Ambassador to Spain, to clarify reports about the NSA's surveillance of the Spanish government.{{cite web|title=Spanish PM summons U. S. ambassador over NSA spying|url=http://www.agi.it/flash-news/articles/201310251547-cro-ren1041-spanish_pm_summons_u_s_ambassador_over_nsa_spying|publisher=[[Agenzia Giornalistica Italia]]|accessdate=October 27, 2013}} Spanish EU Minister [[Íñigo Méndez de Vigo]] said such practices, if true, were "inappropriate and unacceptable". An EU delegation was to meet officials in Washington to convey their concerns.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24708410 |title=NSA surveillance: Spain demands US explain 'monitoring' |publisher=bbc.co.uk |date=October 28, 2013 |accessdate=October 28, 2013}} According to ''The Wall Street Journal'', data allegedly collected by the NSA in Spain was actually collected by Spanish intelligence agencies outside Spain and then shared with the United States.{{cite news|title=U.S. Says France, Spain Aided NSA Spying|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304200804579165653105860502|accessdate=October 29, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|author1=Adam Entous |author2=Siobhan Gorman |lastauthoramp=yes |date=October 29, 2013}} On October 29, ''The Washington Post'' reported that an anonymous "senior Obama administration official" had also described such an arrangement with Spain.{{cite news|title=NSA chief says NATO allies shared phone records with the U.S. spy agency|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/top-intelligence-officials-called-to-testify-on-nsa-surveillance-programs/2013/10/29/e9e9c250-40b7-11e3-a751-f032898f2dbc_story.html|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 29, 2013|author1=Ellen Nakashima |author2=Karen DeYoung |lastauthoramp=yes }} ====UK==== {{See also|Mass surveillance in the United Kingdom}} British Foreign Minister [[William Hague]] admitted that Britain's GCHQ was also spying and collaborating with the NSA, and defended the two agencies' actions as "indispensable."[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/video/2013/jun/09/data-snooping-law-abiding-citizens-nothing-fear-hague-video "Data snooping: law-abiding citizens have 'nothing to fear', says Hague – video"]. ''The Guardian'' (London). June 9, 2013.[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/video/2013/jun/10/nsa-prism-hague-gchq-video "NSA Prism programme: William Hague makes statement on GCHQ – video"]. ''The Guardian'' (London). June 10, 2013.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/25/germany-uk-gchq-internet-surveillance |title= GCHQ surveillance: Germany blasts UK over mass monitoring |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=June 26, 2013 |author1=Travis, Alan |author2=Connolly, Kate |author3=Watt, Nicholas }} Meanwhile, UK Defence officials issued a confidential [[DA-Notice]] to British media asking for restraint in running further stories related to surveillance leaks including the [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] program and the British involvement therein.{{cite web |last=Staines |first=Paul |title=D-Notice, June 7, 2013 |url= http://order-order.com/2013/06/08/d-notice-june-7-2013/ |date=June 8, 2013 |work=Guido Fawkes blog}} British Prime Minister David Cameron issued a veiled threat to resort to [[prior restraint]], through high court injunctions and DA-Notices, if ''The Guardian'' did not obey his demands to stop reporting its revelations on spying by GCHQ and the NSA,{{Cite news | last = Watt | first = Nicholas |date = October 28, 2013 | title = David Cameron makes veiled threat to media over NSA and GCHQ leaks | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/28/david-cameron-nsa-threat-newspapers-guardian-snowden | accessdate = November 3, 2013 | publisher = [[The Guardian|theguardian.com]] }} a development that "alarmed" the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]]{{cite web | title = CPJ alarmed by Cameron's threat against UK press | url = http://cpj.org/2013/10/cpj-alarmed-by-camerons-threat-against-uk-press.php | accessdate = November 3, 2013 | publisher = [[Committee to Protect Journalists|cpj.org]] | date = October 29, 2013 }} and spurred 70 of the world's leading human rights organizations to write an open letter to the newspaper expressing their concern about press and other freedoms in the UK.{{Cite news | last1 = Taylor | first1 = Matthew | last2 = Hopkins | first2 = Nick | date = November 3, 2013 | title = UK government reaction to NSA leaks eroding freedom, rights groups warn | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/03/uk-reaction-nsa-leaks-human-rights | accessdate = November 3, 2013 | publisher = [[The Guardian|theguardian.com]] }}{{Cite news | last = Jouleva | first = Gergana| title = Human rights groups' open letter to David Cameron on surveillance | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/nov/03/human-rights-groups-letter-david-cameron | accessdate = November 3, 2013 | publisher = [[The Guardian|theguardian.com]] |display-authors=etal}} In 2014 the [[Director of the Government Communications Headquarters|Director of GCHQ]] authored an article in the ''[[Financial Times]]'' on the topic of [[internet surveillance]], stating that "however much [large US technology companies] may dislike it, they have become the command and control networks of choice for terrorists and criminals" and that GCHQ and its sister agencies "cannot tackle these challenges at scale without greater support from the private sector", arguing that most internet users "would be comfortable with a better and more sustainable relationship between the [intelligence] agencies and the tech companies". Since the 2013 surveillance disclosures, large US technology companies have improved security and become less co-operative with foreign intelligence agencies, including those of the UK, generally requiring a US court order before disclosing data.{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/c89b6c58-6342-11e4-8a63-00144feabdc0.html |title=The web is a terrorist's command-and-control network of choice |author=Robert Hannigan |newspaper=Financial Times |date=3 November 2014 |accessdate=3 November 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/4a35c0b2-636e-11e4-9a79-00144feabdc0.html |title=Tech groups aid terror, says UK spy chief |author1=Sam Jones |author2=Murad Ahmed |lastauthoramp=yes |newspaper=Financial Times |date=3 November 2014 |accessdate=3 November 2014}} ===North America=== ====Mexico==== On October 24, 2013, the [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Mexican Foreign Minister]] [[José Antonio Meade Kuribreña]] met with U.S. Ambassador [[Earl Anthony Wayne]] to discuss allegations reported by ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' that the NSA hacked the emails of former president [[Felipe Calderón]] while in office.{{cite web|title=Mexico foreign minister meets US envoy over spy claims|url=http://mobile.nation.co.ke/news/Mexico-foreign-minister-meets-US-envoy-over-spy-claims/-/1950946/2047620/-/format/xhtml/-/g9qrh7/-/index.html|publisher=AFP|date=October 25, 2013}} ===Oceania=== ===Australia=== Former [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Australia)|Foreign Minister]] [[Bob Carr]] remarked that the U.S. would be critical of any other nation that failed to prevent the release of such sensitive documents. "Certainly if it had gone the other way," said Carr, "if there'd been some official in Canberra, some contractor in Canberra, who allowed a slew of material as sensitive as this to be plastered over the world's media, America would be saying very stern things to someone they'd be regarding as a woefully immature ally and partner."[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-11-19/indonesia-gives-australia-two-days-to-explain-spying-row/5101050 Spying row: Indonesian president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono accuses Tony Abbott of taking claims too lightly] ====Indonesia==== On November 1, 2013, the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Indonesia)|Foreign Ministry]] of Indonesia summoned [[Australia]]'s Ambassador Greg Moriarty to explain his country's surveillance of President [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]] and other Indonesian political leaders.{{cite web|title=Indonesia Summons Australian Ambassador Over US Spying Allegations|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/indonesia-summons-australian-ambassador-over-us-spying-allegations/1781254.html|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|accessdate=November 4, 2013}} On November 18, the Australian ambassador was summoned again by Indonesian government officials, who pledged to review all types of cooperation with Australia. The Indonesian Foreign Minister [[Marty Natalegawa]] called the spying "unacceptable", and added that "This is an unfriendly, unbecoming act between strategic partners." The Indonesian ambassador to Australia was also recalled as a response to the incident.{{cite web|last=George Roberts|title=Indonesia recalls ambassador after leaked documents reveal Australia spied on president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-11-18/indonesia-angered-by-revelations-australia-spied-on-sby/5100264|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=18 November 2013}} === South America === ====Brazil==== [[File:Greenwald and Miranda at Congress.jpg|thumb|Glenn Greenwald (right) and his partner, Brazilian David Miranda (left), speaking to the [[National Congress of Brazil|National Congress]] of Brazil about U.S. spying activity in that country.]] The Brazilian government expressed outrage at the revelations that the National Security Agency directly targeted the communications of president [[Dilma Rousseff]] and her top aides.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/03/world/americas/brazil-angered-over-report-nsa-spied-on-president.html?_r=0 |title=Brazil Angered Over Report N.S.A. Spied on President |publisher=The New York Times |deadurl=no |accessdate=September 16, 2013 |first1=Simon |last1=Romero |first2=Randal C. |last2=Archibold |date=September 2, 2013}} It called the incident an "unacceptable violation of sovereignty" and requested an immediate explanation from the U.S. government.{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/brazil-reacts-fury-nsa-spying-mexico-orders-probe-1402437 |title=Brazil Reacts With Fury To NSA Spying; Mexico Orders Probe |publisher=International Business Times |deadurl=no |accessdate=September 16, 2013}} Brazil's government signaled it would consider cancelling Rousseff's [[state visit]] to Washington—the only state visit for a foreign leader scheduled this year.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/04/us-usa-security-snowden-brazil-idUSBRE98314N20130904 |title=Exclusive: Brazil's Rousseff wants U.S. apology for NSA spying |publisher=Reuters |deadurl=no |accessdate=September 16, 2013 |date=September 4, 2013}} A senior Brazilian official stated the country would downgrade commercial ties unless Rousseff receives a public apology. That would include ruling out the $4 billion purchase of [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|Boeing F-18 Super Hornet]] fighters and cooperation on oil and biofuels technology, as well as other commercial agreements. [[Petrobras]] announced that it was investing [[Brazilian real|R$]]21 billion over five years to improve its data security.{{cite news | title=Brazil’s Petrobras to invest heavily in data security | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f3195d0a-2081-11e3-9a9a-00144feab7de.html#axzz2gzh4A13k | date=September 18, 2013 | work=Financial Times | location=São Paulo | accessdate=September 18, 2013 | author=Leahy, Joe}} {{Registration}} ====Ecuador==== [[Ecuador]] responded by renouncing U.S. trade benefits and offering to pay a similar amount, $23 million per year, to finance human rights training in America to help avoid what Ecuador's Foreign Minister [[Ricardo Patiño]] called "violations of privacy, torture and other actions that are denigrating to humanity."{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/27/us-usa-security-ecuador-idUSBRE95Q0L820130627 |title= Ecuador offers U.S. rights aid, waives trade benefits |agency=Reuters |date=June 27, 2013}}{{cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/1270475/ecuador-waives-us-trade-rights-after-threats-made-over-snowden-case |title=Ecuador waives US trade rights after threats made over Snowden case |newspaper=South China Morning Post |date=June 28, 2013 |location= Hong Kong}} === Other countries === Russia, South Africa, and Turkey reacted angrily after it was revealed that their diplomats had been spied on during the [[2009 G-20 London summit]].{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/17/turkey-russia-g20-spying-gchq|work=The Guardian|title= G20 summits: Russia and Turkey react with fury to spying revelations|date= June 17, 2013}} === Non-government organizations === ====Index on Censorship==== London-based [[Index on Censorship]] called upon the U.S. government to uphold the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]], saying, "The mass surveillance of citizens' private communications is unacceptable—it both invades privacy and threatens freedom of expression. The US government cannot use the excuse of national security to justify either surveillance on this scale or the extradition of Snowden for revealing it."{{cite web|title=US needs to protect whistleblowers and journalists|url=http://www.indexoncensorship.org/2013/06/us-needs-to-protect-whistleblowers-and-journalists/|publisher=[[Index on Censorship]]|accessdate=August 4, 2013}} ==== United Nations ==== In July 2013, speaking to the foreign affairs committee of the [[Althing|Icelandic Parliament]] in [[Reykjavík]], [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|UN Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] said that in his personal opinion, Edward Snowden had misused his right to digital access and created problems that outweigh the benefits of public disclosure. [[Birgitta Jónsdóttir]], an Icelandic legislator who in 2010 assisted [[WikiLeaks]] in publishing U.S. state secrets leaked by [[Chelsea Manning]], expressed alarm at Ban's remarks. She said that he "seemed entirely unconcerned about the invasion of privacy by governments around the world, and only concerned about how whistleblowers are misusing the system."Pilkington, Ed. "[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/03/edward-snowden-digital-misuse-ban-ki-moon Edward Snowden's digital 'misuse' has created problems, says Ban Ki-moon]." ''[[The Guardian]]''. July 3, 2013. Retrieved July 3, 2013. ==In popular culture== In ''[[The Blacklist (TV series)|The Blacklist]]'' episode "[[The Blacklist episodes|The Alchemist (No. 101)]]" (season 1, episode 12, minutes 00:22:00-00:22:55), one of the technical experts Red tasked to reconstitute documents shredded by American governmental agencies reports: "We actually reached out to the Germans for help. They're the ones who designed the software." Red replies: "Ah, the Germans. Despite recent headlines, they're still the best at keeping an eye on their fellow man".{{cite web|website=Diacritics|url=http://diacritics.org/2014/jade-hidle-vietnamese-german-philipp-rosler-transnational-adoption|author=Hidle, Jade|title=Vietnamese German Philipp Rösler and Transnational Adoption|date= Mar 3, 2014 }}{{cite news|url=http://thetvtimes.co.vu/post/74594648557/the-blacklist-kickass-reddington-quotes-s1-e12-the|title=The Blacklist: Kickass Reddington Quotes (S1:E12) The Alchemist|work=The Times}}{{cite web|website=Den of Geek|title=Review: the blacklist|date=September 30, 2014 |url=http://www.denofgeek.us/taxonomy/term/20736/feed}} == References == {{Reflist|30em|}} [[Category:Global surveillance]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Reactions to 2010s events]]

{{Refimprove|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox civil conflict |title='''Revolutions of 1917–1923''' |partof=the [[aftermath of World War I]] |image=[[File:The people's war book; history, cyclopaedia and chronology of the great world war (1919) (14595451159).jpg|250px]] |caption=[[Bolsheviks|Bolshevik]] revolution in [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Russia|Russia]] (1910s) |date={{start date|1917|3|8|df=y}} – {{circa|}} {{end date|1923|6|16|df=y}} |place=Worldwide (mainly in [[Europe]] and [[Asia]]) |coordinates= |causes= *[[World War I]] *[[Russian Revolution]] {{small|(outside Russia)}} |goals= *[[World communism]] *[[World revolution]] *[[National liberation]] *[[Constitutionalism]] *[[Irredentism]] |methods= |status= |result= *[[Russian Revolution]] *[[Russian Civil War]] *[[German Revolution of 1918-19]] *[[Hungarian Revolution of 1919]] *[[Mongolian Revolution of 1921]] |side1= |side2= |side3= |leadfigures1= |leadfigures2= |leadfigures3= |howmany1= |howmany2= |howmany3= |casualties1= |casualties2= |casualties3= |fatalities= |injuries= |arrests= |detentions= |charged= |fined= |casualties_label= |notes= |sidebox=}} The '''Revolutions of 1917–1923''' were a period of political unrest and revolts around the world inspired by the success of the [[Russian Revolution]] and the disorder created by the [[aftermath of World War I]]. The uprisings were mainly [[socialist]] or [[anti-colonial]] in nature and were mostly short-lived, failing to have a long-term impact.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historytoday.com/david-motadel/waves-revolution |title=Waves of Revolution |last1=Motadel |first1=David |last2= |first2= |date=April 4, 2011 |website=History Today |publisher= |access-date=May 5, 2015 |quote=}}</ref> Out of all the revolutionary activity of the era, the [[revolutionary wave]] of 1917–1923 mainly refers to the unrest caused by [[World War I]] in [[Europe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pnLI8ooHHPgC&pg=PA238&lpg=PA238&dq=1917%E2%80%9323+wave&source=bl&ots=3tb3I4H5ZA&sig=j8d0sgDCa3o0D0fK8fPGymAhdlM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjW0Mr-q8TMAhULKh4KHfsFDlAQ6AEIKjAC#v=onepage&q=1917%E2%80%9323%20wave&f=false |title=Neutral Europe Between War and Revolution, 1917-23 |last1=Schmitt |first1=Hans |publisher= |access-date=May 5, 2016}}</ref>
==Communist revolutions in Europe== ===Russia=== {{Main|Russian Revolution|Russian Civil War}} [[File:Europe map 1919.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Political divisions of Europe in 1919 after the treaties of [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk|Brest-Litovsk]] and [[Treaty of Versailles|Versailles]] but before the treaties of [[Treaty of Trianon|Trianon]], [[Treaty of Lausanne|Lausanne]], and [[Peace of Riga|Riga]] and the creation of the [[Soviet Union]] and the [[Turkey|Turkish Republic]]]]
In war-torn [[Russian Empire|Imperial Russia]], the liberal [[February Revolution]] toppled the monarchy. It was unstable and the [[Bolsheviks]] seized power in the [[October Revolution]]. The ascendant [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|communist party]] soon withdrew from the war with some territorial concessions by the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]]. It then battled its political rivals in the [[Russian Civil War]], including [[Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War|invading forces from the Allied Powers]]. In response to [[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]], the Bolshevik Party and the emerging [[Soviet Union]], [[Anti-communism|anti-communists]] from a broad assortment of ideological factions fought against them, particularly through the [[counter-revolutionary]] [[White movement]] and the peasant [[Green armies|Green Army]], the various nationalist movements in [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution]] and other would-be new states like those in Soviet [[Transcaucasia]] and [[Soviet Central Asia]], through the [[Anarchism|anarchist]]-inspired [[Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks|Third Russian Revolution]] and [[Tambov Rebellion]].<ref>Abraham Ascher, //The Russian Revolution: A Beginner's Guide'' (Oneworld Publications, 2014)</ref>
By 1921, due to exhaustion, the collapse of transportation and markets, and threats of starvation, even dissident elements of the [[Red Army]] itself were in revolt against the [[communist state]], as shown by the [[Kronstadt rebellion]]. However, the multiple anti-Bolshevik forces were uncoordinated and disorganized, and in every case operated on the periphery. The Red Army, operating at the center, defeated them one by one and regained control. The complete failure of Comintern-inspired revolutions was a sobering experience in Moscow, and the Bolsheviks moved from world revolution to the theme of socialism in one country, Russia. Lenin moved to open trade relations with Britain, Germany, and other major countries. Most dramatically, in 1921, Lenin introduced a sort of small-scale capitalism with his [[New Economic Policy]] (or NEP). In this process of revolution and counter-revolution the [[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]] (USSR) was officially born in 1922.<ref>Rex A. Wade, "The Revolution at One Hundred: Issues and Trends in the English Language Historiography of the Russian Revolution of 1917." ''Journal of Modern Russian History and Historiography'' 9.1 (2016): 9-38.</ref>
===Western Europe=== {{Main|German Revolution of 1918–19|Revolutions and interventions in Hungary (1918–20)|Biennio Rosso}} [[File:Berlin.revolution1918.statue.jpg|thumb|Statue of a revolutionary soldier; memorial to the [[German Revolution of 1918–19|German Revolution]] in [[Berlin]]]]
The [[Leninist]] victories also inspired a surge by the [[History of communism|world Communist movement]]: the larger [[German Revolution of 1918–19|German Revolution]] and its offspring, like the [[Bavarian Soviet Republic]], as well as the neighboring [[Revolutions and interventions in Hungary (1918–20)|Hungarian Revolution]], and the [[Biennio Rosso]] in Italy in addition to various smaller uprisings, protests and strikes, all proved abortive.
The Bolsheviks sought to coordinate this new wave of revolution in the Soviet-led [[Communist International]], while new [[Communist party|communist parties]] separated from their former socialist organizations and the older, more moderate [[Second International]]. Despite ambitions for [[world revolution]], the far-flung Comintern movement had more setbacks than successes through the next generation, and it was abolished in 1943.<ref>Kevin McDermott and Jeremy Agnew, ''The Comintern: A History of International Communism from Lenin to Stalin'' (Macmillan, 1996).</ref> After the Second World War when the [[Red Army]] occupied most of Eastern Europe, Communists would come to power in the Baltic states, [[Polish People's Republic|Poland]], [[Hungarian People's Republic|Hungary]], [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovakia]], [[Socialist Republic of Romania|Romania]], [[People's Republic of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]], and [[East Germany]].<ref>Robert Service, ''Comrades!: A History of World Communism'' (2010).</ref>
==Non-Communist revolutions== ===Ireland=== In [[Ireland]], then part of the United Kingdom, the [[Irish nationalism|nationalist]] [[Easter Rising]] of 1916 anticipated the [[Irish War of Independence]] (1919–1921) within the same historical period as this first wave of [[communist revolution]]. The [[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]] movement of the time was predominantly nationalist and [[Populism|populist]], and although it had left-wing positions and included socialists and communists, it was not Communist. The Irish and Soviet Russian Republics nevertheless found common ground in their opposition to [[British Empire|British interests]], and established a trading relationship.
===Mexico=== The same was true of the [[Mexican Revolution]] (1910–1920), which had broken out in 1910 but had devolved into factional fighting among the rebels by 1915, as the more radical forces of [[Emiliano Zapata]] and [[Pancho Villa]] lost ground to the more conservative "Sonoran oligarchy" and its [[Constitutional Army]]. The [[Felicistas]], the last major group of counterrevolutionaries, abandoned their armed campaign in 1920, and the internecine power struggles abated for a time after revolutionary General [[Álvaro Obregón]] had bribed or slain his former allies and rivals alike, but the following decade witnessed the assassination of Obregon and several others, abortive [[Coup d'état|military coup]] attempts and a massive right-wing uprising, the [[Cristero War]], due to religious persecution of Roman Catholics.
===Malta=== The [[Sette Giugno|Sette Giugno of 1919]] was a revolt characterised by a series of riots and protests by the Maltese population, initially as a reaction to the rise in the cost of living in the aftermath of [[World War I]], and the sacking of hundreds of workers from the dockyard. This coincided with popular demands for [[Self-governance|self-government]], which resulted in a National Assembly being formed in Valletta at the same time of the riots. This dramatically boosted the uprising, as many people headed to Valletta to show their support for the Assembly. This led to the British forces firing into the crowd, killing four local men. The cost of living increased dramatically after the war. Imports were limited, and as food became scarce prices rose; this made the fortune of farmers and merchants with surpluses to trade.
===Egypt=== The [[Egyptian Revolution of 1919]] was a countrywide [[revolution]] against the [[United Kingdom|British]] occupation of [[Egypt]] and [[Sudan]]. It was carried out by [[Egyptians]] and Sudanese from different walks of life in the wake of the British-ordered exile of revolutionary leader [[Saad Zaghloul]], and other members of the [[Wafd Party]] in 1919. The revolution led to Britain's [[Unilateral Declaration of Egyptian Independence|recognition of Egyptian independence]] in 1922, and the implementation of a new [[Egyptian Constitution of 1923|constitution in 1923]]. Britain, however, continued in control of what was renamed the [[Kingdom of Egypt]]. British guided the king and retained control of the Canal Zone, [[Sudan]] and Egypt's external and military affairs. King Fuad died in 1936 and [[Farouk of Egypt|Farouk]] inherited the throne at the age of sixteen. Alarmed by the [[Second Italo-Abyssinian War]] when Italy invaded Ethiopia, he signed the [[Anglo-Egyptian Treaty of 1936|Anglo-Egyptian Treaty]], requiring Britain to withdraw all troops from Egypt by 1949, except at the Suez Canal. During World War II, British troops [[Military history of Egypt during World War II|used Egypt]] as a major base for its operations throughout the region. British troops were withdrawn to the Suez Canal area in 1947, but nationalist, anti-British feelings continued to grow after the war.<ref>P.J. Vatikiotis, ''The History of Modern Egypt'' (4th ed., 1992).</ref>

The '''Schøyen Collection''' is the largest private [[manuscript]] collection in the world, mostly located in [[Oslo]] and London. Formed in the 20th century by [[Martin Schøyen]], it comprises manuscripts of global [[provenance]], spanning 5,000 years of history. It contains more than 13,000 manuscript items; the oldest is about 5,300 years old. There are manuscripts from 134 different countries and territories, representing 120 distinct languages.<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/aboutus.html ''The Schøyen Collection'']</ref>
The variety of manuscripts—geographic, linguistic, textual and material—even more than its size makes the Schøyen Collection unique. The collection has a website with many items illustrated and described. The provenance of the various cuneiform materials held by the Schøyen Collection remains subject to controversy.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2004/2004-04-21.html|title=Review of: The Babylonian Gilgamesh Epic: Introduction, Critical Edition and Cuneiform Texts, 2 vols|first=Eleanor|last=Robson|date=1 May 2017|publisher=|journal=BMCR|via=Bryn Mawr Classical Review}}</ref>
== Notable manuscripts == Among the most notable items of the collection are the following: * MS 1 (''ca.'' 1300), a fragment from a [[codex]] of French sermons, in a binding produced by Manuale del Navarro, acquired in 1955 * MS 035, ''Codex Sinaiticus Zosimi Rescriptus'', a [[palimpsest]] on [[vellum]] from [[Mount Sinai]]<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/HebrewAramaic.htm#035 Ms 035] at the ''Schøyen Collection''</ref> * MS 193 (3rd century AD), ''The Crosby-Schøyen Codex'', biblical manuscript in the Coptic language; it contains: Jonah, 2 Maccabees, 1 Peter, "Peri Pascha" of [[Melito of Sardis|Melito]], and an unidentified Homily<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/bibleCoptic.html#193 Ms 193] at the ''Schøyen Collection''</ref> * MS 1717 (31st century BC), The [[Kushim_(individual)|Kushim Tablet]], a [[Sumer]]ian cuneiform record of beer production, signed by possibly the first example of a person named in writing<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/24-smaller-collections/wine-beer/ms-1717-beer-inanna-uruk Ms 1717] at the ''Schøyen Collection''</ref> * MS 2064 (21st century BC), [[Ur-Nammu]]'s law-code, a [[Sumer]]ian text.<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/law.htm#2064 Ms 2064] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070301150456/http://www.schoyencollection.com/law.htm |date=2007-03-01 }} at the ''Schøyen Collection''</ref> * MS 2650 (4th century AD), ''Codex Schøyen'', the oldest [[Gospel of Matthew]] in Coptic dialect<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/Coptic.htm#2650 Ms 2650] at the ''Schøyen Collection''</ref> * MS 2781 (2000–1600 BC), a [[Babylon]]ian calendar.<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/calendars.htm#2781 The Middle Babylonian Almanac] at the ''Schøyen Collection''</ref> * MS 4457 (1865-1879 AD), [[Cheyenne]] Chief [[Little Shield]]'s Ledger Book recording the Indian War of the Platte River in 1865. *MS 108 "The earliest Greek Alphabet” copper,, [[Cyprus]], ca. 800 BC, 2 tablets, 21x13 cm, single column, (19x10 cm), 20-23 lines in archaic Greek capitals with some North Semitic (Phoenician) letter forms by 2 or more scribes. * [[MS 5236]], an ancient Greek [[block print]] from the 6th century BC * [[Tutankhamun]]'s signet ring * Some ancient Buddhist manuscripts taken from Afghanistan, allegedly to preserve them from the [[Taliban]]. * Since 1994, the Schøyen Collection has acquired 115 [[Dead Sea Scrolls]] fragments from 15 different scrolls.<ref>[http://www.schoyencollection.com/dsscrolls.htm Dead Sea Scrolls] at the ''Schøyen Collection''</ref>
